newsitem.title: USA: Conrail stockholders reject CSX merger plan.
newsitem.headline: Conrail stockholders reject CSX merger plan.

text.p: Shareholders of Conrail Inc. Friday voted against a measure crucial to the railroad's planned $9.3 billion merger with CSX Inc., rival bidder Norfolk Southern Corp. said.
Conrail Chairman David LeVan said Conrail would schedule a new shareholder vote. He did not specify a date.
"We will reschedule the meeting. We will move on. We have to get out and sell the value of this transaction," he said.
Norfolk Southern Chief Executive Officer David Goode said at least 53 percent of Conrail's outstanding shares were voted against the measure.
LeVan had insisted before the vote that the Philadelphia-based railroad was committed to its proposed merger with CSX despite a higher, hostile offer from Norfolk Southern.
Conrail has repeatedly rejected Norfolk Southern's $10.3 billion bid, saying that CSX's offer provides more benefits.

"The Conrail board has determined that a sale to Norfolk Southern is not in the best interests of Conrail, and the Conrail board will not agree to a sale to Norfolk Southern," LeVan said in remarks prepared for delivery to the Conrail shareholders meeting.
LeVan said Conrail's board was not swayed by a proposal by Norfolk Southern to buy 9.9 percent of the company if shareholders defeated the measure, which was critical to the CSX union.

"I hope you all understand the Conrail board is fully committed to the CSX-Conrail merger and, regardless of speculation to the contrary, there can be no transaction with Norfolk Southern until 1999 at the earliest," he said.
The proposed merger pact between Conrail and CSX prohibits either party, should their pact fail, from merging with another company until 1999.
